just censoring it because this post is not exactly in D@ny's in favor after all
body:
About the leaks

.

.

.

.

.

.

.

D@ny calling Sansa beautiful might just be a throwback to when Sansa tried to get into good graces with Lyanna Mormont by complimenting her (future) beauty, and Lyanna not falling for it. Sansa is probably like: “Yes, I know that trick, won’t work on me either.“

summary: Hi. First of all, I love your blog. Thank you for all the time and love you pour into this fandom.   HBO is doing a GoT marathon...
question: Hi. First of all, I love your blog. Thank you for all the time and love you pour into this fandom.   HBO is doing a GoT marathon and I happened to watch Jon’s KitN scene last night and Robb’s just now. Both beautiful, emotional scenes. Do you think, based on the rule of three, we’ll have a third one this season? The lords proclaiming this time Sansa as QitN?
answer:
Thank you so much, anon! That’s so sweet of you to say :’)

I honestly don’t know. It could happen, but while it might be beautiful and emotional twice, a third time could easily just end up feeling trite, ykwim? So, if Sansa becomes queen, I hope she gets a scene that’s different and all hers instead of echoing her brothers’ moments. 

Thanks for the ask!

reblog.comment:
Thank you so much, anon! That’s so sweet of you to say :’)

Thanks for the ask!

body:
GoT rewatch

Is anyone else finding themselves intensely emotionally compromised rewatching Game of Thrones? Like I rewatched season 7 and bawled my eyes out the whole time. I’m a grown ass woman who’s crying into my Chinese food over Jaime Lannister trotting off to fulfill his oath. There’s tears in my tiramisu right now because I saw Sansa, Arya and Bran become murder buddies. Like what is happening to me?

Anyway……


How are you guys doing?

blog.name: latenightsinpemberley
blog.title: a dream ago, perhaps
blog.description: “Wake up little girl. They've stolen away your dream; you grew up...”

summary: I still remember the number of hateful comments the likes of ‘of course Sansa shuts up the moment she's given power!’ when Jon...
body:
I still remember the number of hateful comments the likes of ‘of course Sansa shuts up the moment she’s given power!’ when Jon leaves Winterfell in the beginning of Season 7.

You fools.

As if Jon Snow would have survived the battle of the bastards, let alone won it, if it weren’t for Sansa.

As if Jon Snow has any legitimate claim to be Warden of the North over a trueborn daughter, other than the show’s misogynistic narrative.

As if Jon Snow is even remotely as capable a leader as Sansa.

Sansa has absolutely nothing to be grateful for. She’s being generous enough letting him play King at all.

summary: haaaaaaaaaaaah l knew it... that’s what l’ve been saying since forever she loves him and she knows it l mean that was so obvious...
body:
haaaaaaaaaaaah l knew it… that’s what l’ve been saying since forever she loves him and she knows it l mean that was so obvious the  “l wish jon were here”, the  “what does that have to do with anything” “you think he wants to marry her” to littlefinger in season 7…

 that girl  was already in love and ready to  commit incest . 

Sansa asking jon if he bent the knee for love or for the north could be perceived as her just wanted to know if he was dumb enough to bend the knee for  love or because he thought that was the only way to save the north….

when the real motive behind that question is to know if dany took that important place she had in his life and the one she is secretly hoping  she has in his heart .

summary:
Sansa, looking at Margaery: Wow, she's so beautiful.
Tyrion: Don't feel that way, Sansa. You're beautiful too.
Sansa: I'm not...
body:
Sansa, looking at Margaery: Wow, she’s so beautiful.

Tyrion: Don’t feel that way, Sansa. You’re beautiful too.

Sansa: I’m not jealous, Tyrion. I’m bi.

blog.name: secretlyatargaryen
blog.title: Worms are crawling in and out of Rhaegar's ass
blog.description: Jenny. This blog consists mainly of Game of Thrones/A Song of Ice and Fire, with particular focus on Tyrion, but also among my favorites are Sansa, Cersei, Arya, and Brienne. I also occasionally post about video games or books or whatever else I find interesting.

summary: Queen Cersei got to her feet in a rustle of skirts. "Your Grace, in the judgment of your small council, it would be neither...
body:
Queen Cersei got to her feet in a rustle of skirts. “Your Grace, in the judgment of your small council, it would be neither proper nor wise for you to wed the daughter of a man beheaded for treason, a girl whose brother is in open rebellion against the throne even now. Sire, your councillors beg you, for the good of your realm, set Sansa Stark aside. The Lady Margaery will make you a far more suitable queen.”

Like a pack of trained dogs, the lords and ladies in the hall began to shout their pleasure. “Margaery,” they called. “Give us Margaery!” and “No traitor queens! Tyrell! Tyrell!”

While Sansa’s betrothal to Joffrey was ended on the grounds that she was a traitor’s daughter, Tyrion was the one who thought it should be ended because of what Joffrey did.

“If it gives you any solace, I do not intend that you ever wed Joffrey. No marriage will reconcile Stark and Lannister after all that has happened, I fear. More’s the pity. The match was one of King Robert’s better notions, if Joffrey hadn’t mucked it up.“

And consistently sticks up for her when other people blame her for things that aren’t her fault.

"I’m punishing her.”

“For what crime? She did not fight her brother’s battle.”

And of course, Tyrion would be able to relate to being used as a scapegoat for things that aren’t your fault, since he’s been treated the same his whole life.

His grin turned into something softer as he studied her face. “Is it grief for your lord father that makes you so sad?”

“My father was a traitor,” Sansa said at once. “And my brother and lady mother are traitors as well.” That reflex she had learned quickly. “I am loyal to my beloved Joffrey.”

“No doubt. As loyal as a deer surrounded by wolves.”

The phrase “a deer surrounded by wolves” (which of course Sansa changes to lions) also is similar to the analogy Tyrion uses to describe his own situation when he arrives in King’s Landing, surrounded by people who he knows are openly hostile to him.

Cersei could smell weakness the way a dog smells fear.

Which also can be connected to the first quote of this post, about the court behaving like a “pack of trained dogs.”

The idea of being surrounded by vicious animals and having to constantly monitor and modify your behavior is a good analogy for the kind of ptsd that people experience after having to live day after day in hostile conditions.

And Tyrion’s line about Cersei is an under-explored aspect of that relationship, I think. Partly because GRRM later does his best to undercut Cersei and portray her as incompetent, but Tyrion had to live with Cersei and her hostility towards him for years, so his line here sounds like an abuse victim who is afraid of being seen as vulnerable in front of someone who has hurt him in the past. The difference between Tyrion and Sansa is that Tyrion actually does have the power to do something about it, although that power is also limited and we see the end of that limit at the end of ASOS.

“My father was a traitor,” Sansa said at once. “And my brother and lady mother are traitors as well.” That reflex she had learned quickly. “I am loyal to my beloved Joffrey.”

“No doubt. As loyal as a deer surrounded by wolves.”

The phrase “a deer surrounded by wolves” (which of course Sansa changes to lions) also is similar to the analogy Tyrion uses to describe his own situation when he arrives in King’s Landing, surrounded by people who he knows are openly hostile to him.

Cersei could smell weakness the way a dog smells fear.

Which also can be connected to the first quote of this post, about the court behaving like a “pack of trained dogs.”

The idea of being surrounded by vicious animals and having to constantly monitor and modify your behavior is a good analogy for the kind of ptsd that people experience after having to live day after day in hostile conditions.

And Tyrion’s line about Cersei is an under-explored aspect of that relationship, I think. Partly because GRRM later does his best to undercut Cersei and portray her as incompetent, but Tyrion had to live with Cersei and her hostility towards him for years, so his line here sounds like an abuse victim who is afraid of being seen as vulnerable in front of someone who has hurt him in the past. The difference between Tyrion and Sansa is that Tyrion actually does have the power to do something about it, although that power is also limited and we see the end of that limit at the end of ASOS.

body:
read it on the AO3 at https://ift.tt/2FuuuWX

by Shewolf_of_highgarden

Arya spends most of her time at dance lessons, sneaking around with Gendry Waters, and waiting for her elder perfect sister to finally mess up.

When it finally happens Arya is overjoyed, but joy soon turn to dread when she is left to pick up the pieces.
